articles.headline: U.S. Budget Gap Is Revised to Surpass $1.8 Trillion
articles.snippet: The latest projection adds $90 billion to its already historically high estimates of deficits for both this fiscal year and next.
articles.abstract: The latest projection adds $90 billion to its already historically high estimates of deficits for both this fiscal year and next.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama has lately begun pointing to optimistic signs for the economy, but the continuing crisis still bedevils his budget projections and his domestic agenda.

articles.headline: Commander’s Ouster Is Tied to Shift in Afghan War
articles.snippet: The replacement of Gen. David D. McKiernan less than a year after he took over marks a major change in leadership in a worsening war environment.
articles.abstract: The replacement of Gen. David D. McKiernan less than a year after he took over marks a major change in leadership in a worsening war environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David D. McKiernan, was forced out Monday in an abrupt shake-up intended to bring a more aggressive and innovative approach to a worsening seven-year war.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Obama Push to Cut Health Costs Faces Tough Odds
articles.snippet: If history is a guide, the commitments from the health care industry may not produce the promised savings.
articles.abstract: If history is a guide, the commitments from the health care industry may not produce the promised savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama engineered a political coup on Monday by bringing leaders of the health care industry to the White House to build momentum for his ambitious health care agenda.

articles.headline: Russia Stockpiles Diamonds, Awaiting the Return of Demand
articles.snippet: Though it is a major commodity producer, Russia has traditionally not embraced policies that artificially keep prices up. Diamonds are an exception.
articles.abstract: Though it is a major commodity producer, Russia has traditionally not embraced policies that artificially keep prices up. Diamonds are an exception.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  The global recession sapped demand for all kinds of commodities  like steel and grain  yet small burlap bags are still arriving by the planeload at Russia’s state-owned diamond company.

articles.headline: As Storefronts Become Vacant, Ads Arrive
articles.snippet: Rather than let abandoned retail spaces look like pockets of poverty, landlords are renting the windows out to marketers for street-level advertising displays.
articles.abstract: Rather than let abandoned retail spaces look like pockets of poverty, landlords are renting the windows out to marketers for street-level advertising displays.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost every category of advertising is declining precipitously in this economy, but there is one that is thriving.

articles.headline: Print Books Are Target of Pirates on the Web
articles.snippet: E-reader technology is making it easier to obtain and distribute copyrighted material on the Web for free.
articles.abstract: E-reader technology is making it easier to obtain and distribute copyrighted material on the Web for free.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ursula K. Le Guin, the science fiction writer, was perusing the Web site Scribd last month when she came across digital copies of some books that seemed quite familiar to her. No wonder. She wrote them, including a free-for-the-taking copy of one of her most enduring novels, “The Left Hand of Darkness.”

articles.headline: We’re Dull, Small Banks Say, but Have Profits
articles.snippet: Community banks have hardly suffered in the credit crisis, in part because they prefer to be boring — and safe.
articles.abstract: Community banks have hardly suffered in the credit crisis, in part because they prefer to be boring — and safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS  It’s unlikely that any group of professionals is happier to highlight the dullness of their work than small-town bankers.

articles.headline: Workers Pressure Bank to Keep Clothier’s U.S. Plants Open
articles.snippet: Workers at the men’s clothing maker Hartmarx are hoping to save their jobs by pressuring the bankrupt company’s main creditor to approve a sale that would keep the company alive.
articles.abstract: Workers at the men’s clothing maker Hartmarx are hoping to save their jobs by pressuring the bankrupt company’s main creditor to approve a sale that would keep the company alive.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES PLAINES, Ill.  Hartmarx, known for its Hart Schaffner & Marx and Hickey Freeman suits, and for making President Obama’s inauguration tuxedo and topcoat, has long been America’s leading clothier for men. Now its workers want to make the company, which is in bankruptcy, a leader in a different way.
